intro: Taverniera glauca, commonly known as the bluebells of the Canary Islands, is a flowering plant native to the island of Tenerife. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its striking blue to purple flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in rocky or coastal areas, showcasing its adaptability to harsh environmental conditions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in a fine, powdery bloom, giving them a distinctive silvery appearance. Taverniera glauca plays an important role in the local ecosystem, providing nectar for pollinators and contributing to the unique biodiversity of the Canary Islands.
